articles.headline: A State Backs Guns in Class for Teachers
articles.snippet: South Dakota became the first state to enact a law explicitly authorizing school employees to carry guns on the job, under a measure signed Friday by Gov. Dennis Daugaard.
articles.abstract: South Dakota became the first state to enact a law explicitly authorizing school employees to carry guns on the job, under a measure signed Friday by Gov. Dennis Daugaard.
articles.lead_paragraph: South Dakota became the first state in the nation to enact a law explicitly authorizing school employees to carry guns on the job, under a measure signed into law on Friday by Gov. Dennis Daugaard.

articles.headline: The Headache in Housewares for J.C. Penney
articles.snippet: A marketing deal between J. C. Penney and Martha Stewart, the subject of a court battle this week, offers a window into the management skills of the company’s chief executive, Ron Johnson.
articles.abstract: A marketing deal between J. C. Penney and Martha Stewart, the subject of a court battle this week, offers a window into the management skills of the company’s chief executive, Ron Johnson.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ron Johnson, the former head of retail at Apple and now the chief executive of J. C. Penney, testified this week that he’d never ask anyone to breach a contract. He said he believed in “perfect integrity” as “a matter of principle,” and he readily agreed with the premise that “it’s important to honor contracts even if the terms are unlikable at the time.”

articles.headline: J.&J. Loses First Case Over Faulty Hip Implant
articles.snippet: A jury ordered $8.3 million in damages in the first of some 10,000 lawsuits tied to a now-recalled implant.
articles.abstract: A jury ordered $8.3 million in damages in the first of some 10,000 lawsuits tied to a now-recalled implant.
articles.lead_paragraph: A jury in Los Angeles on Friday ordered Johnson & Johnson to pay more than $8.3 million in damages to a Montana man in the first of more than 10,000 lawsuits pending against the medical products maker in connection with a now-recalled artificial hip.

articles.headline: In New Euro Boss, a Hard-Line Future
articles.snippet: The doctrine of Jeroen Dijsselbloem, the head of the Eurogroup, could mean that bondholders end up absorbing steep losses if euro zone members are called upon to prop up failing banks.
articles.abstract: The doctrine of Jeroen Dijsselbloem, the head of the Eurogroup, could mean that bondholders end up absorbing steep losses if euro zone members are called upon to prop up failing banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — When George Zannakis, a Greek sound engineer, heeded his investment adviser’s guidance in January by plowing half of his life savings into a high-yield bond issued by the Dutch bank SNS Reaal, he did not consider it a high-risk proposition.

articles.headline: For Parents-to-Be, a Few Financial and Legal Tips
articles.snippet: Having a baby is a wonderfully happy time and also a stressful one, so it pays to get your financial house in order for the sake of you, your partner and your new child.
articles.abstract: Having a baby is a wonderfully happy time and also a stressful one, so it pays to get your financial house in order for the sake of you, your partner and your new child.
articles.lead_paragraph: Once you hold your new baby in your arms for the first time, the last thing on your mind is all of the money-related tasks and decisions you have to make.

articles.headline: Major Grocer to Label Foods With Gene-Modified Content
articles.snippet: Whole Foods, the first retailer in the country to require such labeling, said all foods sold in its stores would need to be labeled within five years.
articles.abstract: Whole Foods, the first retailer in the country to require such labeling, said all foods sold in its stores would need to be labeled within five years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Whole Foods Market, the grocery chain, on Friday became the first retailer in the United States to require labeling of all genetically modified foods sold in its stores, a move that some experts said could radically alter the food industry.

articles.headline: Visions of Drones Swarming U.S. Skies Hit Bipartisan Nerve
articles.snippet: The Big Brother imagery conjured up by Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky during a filibuster this week has animated a diverse swath of political interests.
articles.abstract: The Big Brother imagery conjured up by Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky during a filibuster this week has animated a diverse swath of political interests.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The debate goes to the heart of a deeply rooted American suspicion about the government, the military and the surveillance state: the specter of drones streaking through the skies above American cities and towns, controlled by faceless bureaucrats and equipped to spy or kill.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Blocked Bids to Fill Judgeships Stir New Fight on Filibuster
articles.snippet: Republican senators have so far kept President Obama from filling any of the four vacancies on the nation’s most important appeals court, reviving talk of a change in Senate rules.
articles.abstract: Republican senators have so far kept President Obama from filling any of the four vacancies on the nation’s most important appeals court, reviving talk of a change in Senate rules.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A fresh feud over federal judgeships has again begun to agitate the Senate, with Republicans so far blocking President Obama from filling any of the four vacancies on the nation’s most prestigious and important appeals court.

articles.headline: Setback to Boeing’s Hopes for Longer Range for 787
articles.snippet: Because of recent incidents with the jet’s battery, an advanced feature allowing for new flight paths may not receive approval for months, which could dilute the jet’s appeal.
articles.abstract: Because of recent incidents with the jet’s battery, an advanced feature allowing for new flight paths may not receive approval for months, which could dilute the jet’s appeal.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the technologically advanced 787, Boeing offered airlines big fuel savings and better comfort for passengers. It also promised something else: the ability to reach just about any airport on the globe without having to stop.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Christopher Drew

articles.headline: In Parts of Syria, Lack of Assistance ‘Is a Catastrophe’
articles.snippet: The vast majority of foreign aid is going to territory controlled by President Bashar al-Assad while the small amount reaching opposition-held areas is all but invisible.
articles.abstract: The vast majority of foreign aid is going to territory controlled by President Bashar al-Assad while the small amount reaching opposition-held areas is all but invisible.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAWRAN, Syria — The United States and other international donors are spending hundreds of millions of dollars on humanitarian aid for Syrians afflicted by the civil war. But here in the rebel-controlled north, where the deprivation is most acute, that money has bought mostly anger and resentment: the vast majority of aid is going to territory controlled by President Bashar al-Assad, and the small amount reaching opposition-held areas is all but invisible.

articles.headline:
How a U.S.
    Citizen Came to
    Be in America’s
    Cross Hairs
articles.snippet: An account of how the United States came to use a drone strike to kill the American-born terrorist leader Anwar al-Awlaki highlights the perils of a war conducted behind a classified veil.
articles.abstract: An account of how the United States came to use a drone strike to kill the American-born terrorist leader Anwar al-Awlaki highlights the perils of a war conducted behind a classified veil.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One morning in late September 2011, a group of American drones took off from an airstrip the C.I.A. had built in the remote southern expanse of Saudi Arabia. The drones crossed the border into Yemen, and were soon hovering over a group of trucks clustered in a desert patch of Jawf Province, a region of the impoverished country once renowned for breeding Arabian horses.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti, Charlie Savage and Scott Shane

articles.headline: Corralling Mobsters, if Not Many Big Banks
articles.snippet: Mary Jo White, nominated to head the S.E.C., has a long résumé as a prosecutor, though it includes few cases against large financial institutions.
articles.abstract: Mary Jo White, nominated to head the S.E.C., has a long résumé as a prosecutor, though it includes few cases against large financial institutions.
articles.lead_paragraph: EVERYONE knows about the mobsters and terrorists that Mary Jo White successfully put behind bars during her nine years as United States attorney for the Southern District of New York. Less well-known is Ms. White’s record bringing cases against large financial institutions during her stint as the top criminal prosecutor in New York.

articles.headline: The Price of Marriage in China
articles.snippet: China’s economic rise has bred a new type of matchmaker — the love hunter — for those wishing to outsource their romantic search.
articles.abstract: China’s economic rise has bred a new type of matchmaker — the love hunter — for those wishing to outsource their romantic search.
articles.lead_paragraph: FROM her stakeout near the entrance of an H & M store in Joy City, a Beijing shopping mall, Yang Jing seemed lost in thought, twirling a strand of her auburn-tinted hair, tapping her nails on an aquamarine iPhone 4S. But her eyes kept moving. They tracked the clusters of young women zigzagging from Zara to Calvin Klein Jeans. They lingered on a face, a gesture, and then moved on, darting across the atrium, searching.

articles.headline: Recipe for Divided Europe: Add Horse, Then Stir
articles.snippet: At a time of immense strains brought on by the euro crisis and austerity, the horse meat scandal has brought into the open the deep divisions that bedevil Europe.
articles.abstract: At a time of immense strains brought on by the euro crisis and austerity, the horse meat scandal has brought into the open the deep divisions that bedevil Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: OLOMOUC, Czech Republic — For Zuzana Navelkova, it was just another day at the office. She showed up for work last month and found a two-pound bag of frozen Swedish meatballs awaiting her attention.

articles.headline: Power Struggle on Reforming Vatican Bank
articles.snippet: The Vatican is under mounting pressure to clean up its bank — long the subject of dark intrigue — in a push by the European Union to apply common rules for the use of the euro.
articles.abstract: The Vatican is under mounting pressure to clean up its bank — long the subject of dark intrigue — in a push by the European Union to apply common rules for the use of the euro.
articles.lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Negotiations over the Vatican’s adherence to international banking standards were reaching a delicate point. During a lunch, a European official later recalled, discussion turned to the need for more openness from an institution steeped in centuries of secrecy.
articles.byline: By Rachel Donadio and Andrew Higgins

articles.headline: Too Young to Retire, but These Deals Can’t Wait
articles.snippet: Baby boomers are finding themselves drawn to condos at retirement communities where prices have plunged since the recession.
articles.abstract: Baby boomers are finding themselves drawn to condos at retirement communities where prices have plunged since the recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOCA RATON, Fla. — Susan Shapira, who is 58, recently moved into a condominium in Century Village, a gated retirement community here where most residents are almost as old as the name.
articles.byline: By Howard Goodman and Michael Winerip

articles.headline: Share of Homes With Guns Shows 4-Decade Decline
articles.snippet: The rate has fallen from an average of 50 percent in the 1970s to 35 percent in the 2000s, suggesting a shift in demographics even as the debate over gun control remains contentious.
articles.abstract: The rate has fallen from an average of 50 percent in the 1970s to 35 percent in the 2000s, suggesting a shift in demographics even as the debate over gun control remains contentious.
articles.lead_paragraph: The share of American households with guns has declined over the past four decades, a national survey shows, with some of the most surprising drops in the South and the Western mountain states, where guns are deeply embedded in the culture.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise and Robert Gebeloff

articles.headline: Disruptions: Digital Era Redefining Etiquette
articles.snippet: Think of how long it takes to access your voice mail and listen to one of those long-winded messages. In text messages, you don’t have to declare who you are, or even say hello.
articles.abstract: Think of how long it takes to access your voice mail and listen to one of those long-winded messages. In text messages, you don’t have to declare who you are, or even say hello.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some people are so rude. Really, who sends an e-mail or text message that just says “Thank you”? Who leaves a voice mail message when you don’t answer, rather than texting you? Who asks for a fact easily found on Google?

articles.headline: Afghan Leader Says U.S. Abets Taliban’s Goal
articles.snippet: President Hamid Karzai charged that the American government and the Taliban had in effect colluded to keep Afghanistan unstable in order to justify a continued American military presence.
articles.abstract: President Hamid Karzai charged that the American government and the Taliban had in effect colluded to keep Afghanistan unstable in order to justify a continued American military presence.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Hamid Karzai leveled particularly harsh accusations against the United States on Sunday, suggesting that the Americans and the Taliban had a common goal in destabilizing his country. The comments cast a shadow on the first visit by Chuck Hagel as defense secretary.
articles.byline: By Alissa J. Rubin and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: After Cashing In on Job Cuts, Wall St. Looks to Worker Upturn
articles.snippet: With jobs slowly coming back, hopes are that ordinary Americans will finally feel the recovery that the nation’s corporations have seen for some time.
articles.abstract: With jobs slowly coming back, hopes are that ordinary Americans will finally feel the recovery that the nation’s corporations have seen for some time.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street is hopeful that American companies, after years of gaining ground at the expense of their employees, will start to succeed because of the rising fortune of those workers.

articles.headline: Click for Career Enhancement
articles.snippet: CreativeLive and other online companies have tapped into an audience of customers who are motivated to hone skills that might enhance their careers, and investors are noticing the profit potential.
articles.abstract: CreativeLive and other online companies have tapped into an audience of customers who are motivated to hone skills that might enhance their careers, and investors are noticing the profit potential.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Anyone who wants to learn calculus, statistics or ancient Greek history can take free online courses in those subjects at a variety of sites from instructors with distinguished academic pedigrees. For more mundane pursuits, like learning how to paddleboard or build a planter box for the garden, there is an inexhaustible supply of free how-to videos on YouTube, eHow and other sites.

articles.headline: Martha’s Brand Struggling for Right Fit
articles.snippet: As Martha Stewart shifts away from media and toward merchandising, a lawsuit between Macy’s and J. C. Penney has highlighted retailers’ continued hunger for strong brands like hers.
articles.abstract: As Martha Stewart shifts away from media and toward merchandising, a lawsuit between Macy’s and J. C. Penney has highlighted retailers’ continued hunger for strong brands like hers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Media companies are often closely associated with their founders — Rupert Murdoch at News Corporation and Sumner Redstone at Viacom come to mind — but none are linked with their products in quite the way Martha Stewart is.

articles.headline: South Korea Flirts With Nuclear Ideas as North Blusters
articles.snippet: North Korea’s threats of war have led to a new sense of vulnerability among South Koreans that is causing some to push for a nuclear arsenal in their country.
articles.abstract: North Korea’s threats of war have led to a new sense of vulnerability among South Koreans that is causing some to push for a nuclear arsenal in their country.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — As their country prospered, South Koreans have largely shrugged off the constant threat of a North Korean attack. But breakthroughs in the North’s missile and nuclear programs and fiery threats of war have heightened fears in the South that even small miscalculations by the new and untested leaders of each country could have disastrous consequences.
articles.byline: By Martin Fackler and Choe Sang-Hun

articles.headline: Algorithms Get a Human Hand in Steering Web
articles.snippet: Computer algorithms are capable of trading stocks, arranging dates and winning “Jeopardy.” But increasingly, behind the curtain, there is a human helper.
articles.abstract: Computer algorithms are capable of trading stocks, arranging dates and winning “Jeopardy.” But increasingly, behind the curtain, there is a human helper.
articles.lead_paragraph: Trading stocks, targeting ads, steering political campaigns, arranging dates, besting people on “Jeopardy” and even choosing bra sizes: computer algorithms are doing all this work and more.

articles.headline: Before Smoke Rises at Vatican, It’s Romans vs. the Reformers
articles.snippet: Beneath an orderly display, the cardinals at the papal conclave are split into competing lineups and power blocs that will determine who among them emerges as pope.
articles.abstract: Beneath an orderly display, the cardinals at the papal conclave are split into competing lineups and power blocs that will determine who among them emerges as pope.
articles.lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — The cardinals who enter the papal conclave on Tuesday will walk into the Sistine Chapel in a single file, but beneath the orderly display, they are split into competing lineups and power blocs that will determine which man among them emerges as pope.
articles.byline: By Laurie Goodstein and Elisabetta Povoledo

articles.headline: After Rough Patch, ‘The Bachelor’ Wins Back Viewers
articles.snippet: After several seasons in decline, ABC’s “The Bachelor” has had a resurgence rare among network reality shows thanks to social media, casting and a push to attract younger viewers.
articles.abstract: After several seasons in decline, ABC’s “The Bachelor” has had a resurgence rare among network reality shows thanks to social media, casting and a push to attract younger viewers.
articles.lead_paragraph: No matter which contestant Sean Lowe, the chiseled, strawberry blond, chooses as his fantasy fiancée on the three-hour season finale of ABC’s “The Bachelor” on Monday — will it be Catherine Giudici, 26, a quirky graphic designer from Seattle, or Lindsay Yenter, 25, a petite substitute teacher from Fort Bragg, N.C.? — the network has rekindled the romance between the reality series and its viewers.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Bill Carter

articles.headline: Cuts Give Obama Path to Create Leaner Military
articles.snippet: Officials see an opening to argue for cuts in bases and health and weapons programs that have long been in President Obama’s sights.
articles.abstract: Officials see an opening to argue for cuts in bases and health and weapons programs that have long been in President Obama’s sights.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At a time when $46 billion in mandatory budget cuts are causing anxiety at the Pentagon, administration officials see one potential benefit: there may be an opening to argue for deep reductions in programs long in President Obama’s sights, and long resisted by Congress.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: Smaller States Find Outsize Clout Growing in Senate
articles.snippet: The disproportionate power enjoyed in the Senate by small states is playing a growing role in the political dynamic on issues as varied as gun control, immigration and campaign finance.
articles.abstract: The disproportionate power enjoyed in the Senate by small states is playing a growing role in the political dynamic on issues as varied as gun control, immigration and campaign finance.
articles.lead_paragraph: RUTLAND, Vt. — In the four years after the financial crisis struck, a great wave of federal stimulus money washed over Rutland County. It helped pay for bridges, roads, preschool programs, a community health center, buses and fire trucks, water mains and tanks, even a project to make sure fish could still swim down the river while a bridge was being rebuilt.
